docs.lead_paragraph: The Near Eastside, a rundown Indianapolis neighborhood, is benefiting from the refurbishing the downtown area is undergoing in anticipation of the first Super Bowl to be played in the city.

headline.seo: Near Eastside Section of Indianapolis Benefits From Super Bowl Bid
headline.main: Unexpected Benefits From a Super Bowl Bid
headline.print_headline: Unexpected Benefits From a Super Bowl Bid

docs.abstract: Rundown Near Eastside neighborhood of Indianapolis is benefiting from rebuilding efforts in the downtown area in anticipation of the Super Bowl, the first to be played in the city.
docs.snippet: The Near Eastside, a rundown Indianapolis neighborhood, is benefiting from the refurbishing the downtown area is undergoing in anticipation of the first Super Bowl to be played in the city.

docs.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS -- The Colts' uncharacteristically wretched season -- the perennial N.F.L. playoff contenders finished 2-14 -- has dimmed some of the luster of the first Super Bowl to be played here, on Feb. 5. But residents can take some consolation from a mini-building boom in anticipation of the big game, with its 150,000 expected visitors and worldwide television audience. The centerpiece is a 1,000-room J. W. Marriott hotel, a 34-story swoosh of Colts-blue glass that will serve as media headquarters. And the city will spend a total of $187 million on infrastructure like bridges, sidewalks, streets and parks. For fans there is Tailgate Town, a winter playground with a turf field, interactive games and an 80-foot-high zip line. It will connect to the Indiana Convention Center, where the league will have the 800,000-square-foot N.F.L. Experience fan festival.

headline.main: Unexpected Benefits From a Super Bowl Bid

docs.lead_paragraph: After a week in Washington, Representative Michael G. Grimm returns to Staten Island to go to church, work out at the gym and head over to Queens for some of his mother’s pasta.

headline.seo: Rep. Michael Grimm Recharges Body and Soul on Sundays

docs.abstract: Rep Michael G Grimm, freshman United States congressman representing Staten Island who has been a Marine, an undercover FBI agent and a health food restaurant owner, describes his typical Sunday routine.
docs.snippet: After a week in Washington, Representative Michael G. Grimm returns to Staten Island to go to church, work out at the gym and head over to Queens for some of his mother’s pasta.
